i.b: Alternatives Analysis and Conceptual Design Report

Partnerships Program, Environmental Stewardship Fund, administered by the
Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources, Bureau of
Recreation and Conservation. This project was also fi nanced, in part, through
a Federal Coastal Zone Management Grant, administered by the Pennsylvania

text.b: Cobbs Creek Connector Trail - Alternatives Analysis and Conceptual Design

text.i: CSX Bridge over Cobbs Creek Parkway

page.text: The proposed Cobbs Creek Connector Trail is a critical missing link in the East
Coast Greenway, a planned path system that will create a non-motorized route
from Maine to Florida. In the Greater Philadelphia region, the Cobbs Creek
Connector Trail will be part of a 750-mile planned network of interconnected
trails known as “The Circuit” (shown in Figure 1) and will directly connect with
several trails including the existing Cobbs Creek Bikeway, the existing John Heinz
Wildlife Refuge Trail, and the proposed Darby Creek Trail.
The Cobbs Creek Connector Trail will enhance pedestrian and bicycle access to
some of Philadelphia’s ﬁ nest historical, natural, and recreational resources. The
trail will wind past Fairmount Park’s historic Blue Bell Inn; recreational facilities
such as the Cibotti Recreation Center and Eastwick Community Park; and the
John Heinz National Wildlife Refuge. Ultimately, Delaware County parks such
as Bosacco Park, Tribett Place Playground and Frank Burr Field would connect
to the trail. The trail will also improve access to and from a myriad of public
transportation options in southwest Philadelphia including bus, trolley, and
In addition to its transportation function, the trail is intended to provide social
and environmental beneﬁ ts to local neighborhoods in both Philadelphia and
Delaware County. By providing the community with a pathway for jogging,
hiking and biking, the completed trail will encourage increased ﬁ tness and
enhance access to the region’s green space. Providing a safe, convenient, and
comfortable pedestrian and bicycle route is also important for school age
children, and the trail may help to reduce vehicle emissions by converting motor
vehicle trips into walking and bicycling trips.
The purpose of this Clean Air Council-sponsored project is to advance planning
and conceptual design for approximately two miles of new trail between the
existing northern terminus of the Cobbs Creek Trail at 70th Street and the John
Heinz National Wildlife Refuge at the southern end. Planning for the Cobbs Creek
Connector Trail involves identifying alignment alternatives along the length of
the trail corridor, evaluating the feasibility of these alternatives, and ultimately

Tr a i l s i n P r o g r e s s

text.b: Figure 1: The Circuit - Regional Trail Network

page.text: recommending a proposed trail alignment. Conceptual design involves
developing what are commonly referred to as “30 percent” drawings, which
show basic alignment and topographic information without the level of detail
The 2007 Cobbs Creek Connector Trail Feasibility Study (Clean Air Council, March
2007) assessed the beneﬁ ts of trail development, inventoried existing conditions,
deﬁ ned a preliminary trail alignment, and outlined next steps for funding
and maintenance. The study also identiﬁ ed four priority segments along the
4 – 84th Street to the John Heinz National Wildlife Refuge
A number of related planning studies also provided context for the current eﬀ ort:
Trail Master Plan for Cobbs Creek Park (Fairmount Park Commission, April

text.i: Trail Development Study for the Tinicum-Fort Miffl
Improving Pedestrian and Bicycle Access to the John Heinz National

page.text: Cobbs Creek – A Gateway to Many Places and to Cleaner Water (Darby-

text.i: Transit and Trail Connections: Assessment of Visitor Access to National

page.text: Wildlife Refuges (US Fish and Wildlife Service, December 2010)
Source: 2007 Cobbs Creek Connector Feasiblity Study
The Study Team for this project was comprised of Urban Engineers, Inc. (Urban),
Lager Raabe Skafte Landscape Architects (LRSLA), and Conestoga–Rovers &
Associates (CRA). As the prime consultant, Urban managed the project and led
the planning and engineering tasks. LRSLA provided landscape and stormwater
management design expertise along key segments of the trail corridor, while
CRA performed natural resource analysis and habitat assessment.
A Steering Committee was formed to guide the study process. The committee
included stakeholders from the Clean Air Council, Pennsylvania Environmental
Council (PEC), Amtrak, CSX, John Heinz National Wildlife Refuge (JHNWR),
Philadelphia Parks & Recreation (PP&R), Philadelphia Streets Department,
Philadelphia City Planning Commission (PCPC), Philadelphia Water Department
(PWD), Philadelphia Redevelopment Authority (PRA), and the Mayors Oﬃ
Transportatoin & Utilities (MOTU). Three Steering Committee meetings were
held over the course of the project (available meeting minutes are included in

text.i: Steering Committee Meeting #1 and Field View (June 28, 2011)

page.text: A kickoﬀ meeting was held to familiarize the Steering Committee with the
trail project and corridor. Urban presented an overview of the project scope
and schedule, which was followed by a discussion about data needs, parcel
ownership, and potentially challenging areas. Following the meeting, the group
walked the project corridor to understand existing conditions and identify
Urban presented a preliminary set of trail alignment alternatives and received
feedback from Steering Committee members. Several alternatives were dropped
based on feasibility issues, while others were carried forward for further analysis.
Planning for the upcoming community meetings occurred at this meeting.
Urban presented a candidate trail alignment for the corridor, which had been
developed and reﬁ ned since the previous meeting. The Steering Committee
discussed and agreed on several changes to the alignment and selected the
Several meetings were held to inform community members about and
seek input for the project. The ﬁ rst round of community meetings was held
during the alternatives analysis phase to obtain feedback on the preliminary
concepts. Meetings were held at both the north and south end of the corridor
to encourage participation from residents. The second community meeting
was held to present the proposed trail alignment for comment. Flyers were
distributed for each meeting (included in Appendix A) and advertisements were
placed in the Southwest Globe Times. The Clean Air Council also canvassed local
neighborhoods to promote awareness of the project and meetings.

text.i: Community Meeting #1 - North End of the Corridor (October 19, 2011)

page.text: This meeting was held at the Paschalville Branch of the Free Library from 4:00
to 7:00 pm and was attended by 8 individuals. The meeting was held in an
open house format with a series of boards displaying the preliminary alignment

text.i: Community Meeting #1 - South End of the Corridor (October 26, 2011)

page.text: A meeting with the same format was held at the Cibotti Recreation Center from
4:00 to 7:00 pm and was attended by 23 individuals.
Following selection of the proposed trail alignment, a ﬁ nal community meeting
was held at the Cibotti Recreation Center from 6:00 to 8:00 pm to gather
feedback from local residents and answer questions about the project. The
Study Team delivered a slideshow presentation covering the project background,
alternatives analysis process, and proposed trail alignment, which was followed
by a question and answer session. A series of boards displaying the proposed
trail alignment were also set up in the room. The meeting was attended by 23
The Study Team and Clean Air Council met with key stakeholders and interest
groups over the course of the project to discuss speciﬁ c project elements. A list
of the meetings is provided below (available meeting minutes are included in
The proposed trail corridor extends for approximately two miles between the
existing Cobbs Creek Trail (CCT) terminus at 70th Street to the north and the
John Heinz National Wildlife Refuge (JHNWR) to the south. Flowing in a southerly
direction, Cobbs Creek forms the western boundary of the corridor, while a
collection of streets including 70th Street, Woodland Avenue, Island Avenue, and
Lindbergh Boulevard form the eastern boundary.
The trail corridor is located in a heavily developed and densely populated setting.
Adjacent land uses along the corridor are mainly residential, with pockets of
commercial and industrial uses. Community institutions and assets such as the
Cibotti Recreation Center, Penrose Elementary School, Motivation High School,
and Eastwick Community Park are located within close proximity to the trail
Though the Cobbs Creek trail corridor is highly urbanized and heavily impacted
by past and current land use practices, it nevertheless oﬀ ers signiﬁ cant natural,
socioeconomic and cultural features, and more importantly, the potential for
enhancement and preservation of these features. Natural resources include the
creek itself and associated ﬂ oodplain and riparian forests. The trail corridor is also
an important wildlife travel corridor by virtue of its proximity and connection to
the John Heinz National Wildlife Refuge, the presence of extensive designated
parklands and other undeveloped open space, and the corridor’s connectivity
with parks/open space in the upper portions of the watershed.
The John Heinz National Wildlife Refuge is, in and of itself, an important wildlife
resource. The Refuge contains the largest contiguous tract of freshwater
tidal marsh in Pennsylvania, and is habitat for a variety of bird, mammal, and
reptile/amphibian species, including one of the few locations where the State-
endangered red-bellied turtle and the coastal leopard frog can be found.
Several known and potential historic resources are located in the trail corridor.
Most notable is the Blue Bell Inn, located at the corner of the Cobbs Creek
Parkway and Woodland Avenue. The Inn, built in 1776, is listed on the National
Register of Historic Places and was the site of a battle between Revolutionary
and British forces in 1777. Other known and potential properties of historic
signiﬁ cance along the trail corridor include the Amtrak and CSX railroad bridges.
Parks and recreational features along the corridor are extensive. From north to
south, these resources include the Cobbs Creek Park (between 70th Street and
Woodland Avenue), Colwyn and Bosacco Parks (downstream of the Amtrak
railroad bridge in Delaware County), the Cibotti Recreation Center (between
77th and 78th Streets), and Eastwick Community Park (adjoining the Eastwick
The 2007 Cobbs Creek Connector Trail Feasibility Study deﬁ ned a preliminary
long-term alignment and broke the overall trail corridor into four segments
based on key roadway crossings. These segments were retained for this study
and are deﬁ ned as follows:
Base mapping was developed for the entire two mile project length extending
from just north of the existing trail terminus at 70th Street to just south of the
JHNWR entrance at 86th Street. Mapping layers and sources included:
The Study Team conducted several site visits to reﬁ ne and conﬁ rm the base
mapping in key areas based on ﬁ eld measurements and photography. Spot
measurements were used to check information from the GIS mapping, including
edge of pavement, cartway widths, drainage features, slopes, and horizontal
and vertical clearances at structures. It was important to accurately locate these
features in order to evaluate impacts during the alternatives analysis.
Another key element of the data collection eﬀ ort was determining the extent
of public right-of-way (ROW) along the trail corridor, as the availability of public
ROW was an important factor in evaluating the feasibility of certain alignments.
Parcel lines were established by compiling and reconciling information from the
The study area consists of a dense roadway network consisting of local
neighborhood streets and regional collectors and arterials. PennDOT-owned
roads in the study area include the Cobbs Creek Parkway (SR 3015), Island Avenue
(SR 3013), Elmwood Avenue (SR 3021) east of Island Avenue, and 84th Street
(SR 3002) in Philadelphia and Main Street (SR 2005) in Delaware County. The
remainder of the roads are owned and maintained by the City of Philadelphia.
To understand the performance of the existing street network and evaluate
c impacts for the on-road alternatives, classiﬁ ed (trucks, buses, cars,
bicycles, pedestrians) manual turning movement counts were performed for the
evening peak period (4:00-6:00 pm) at the following ﬁ ve locations:
Cobbs Creek Parkway (SR 3015) and Church Lane/70th Street
Cobbs Creek Parkway (SR 3015) and Greenway Avenue
c signal plans and timings were also obtained at these intersections to
provide a basis for evaluating traﬃ
c operations and planning for pedestrian and
Based on the characteristics and limits of the proposed trail alternatives, traﬃ
analysis was only performed at the Cobbs Creek Parkway/Church Lane/70th
Street and 84th Street/Lindbergh Boulevard intersections. Analysis of existing
conditions indicates that both intersections currently operate at a Level of
Service “F” with overall intersection delay exceeding 100 seconds per vehicle.
c count data, intersection diagrams, and traﬃ
The trail corridor is well served by public transportation, as SEPTA operates
several bus and trolley lines connecting the study area to other parts of the City
Route 11 Trolley runs along Woodland Avenue and connects Center
City to the Darby Transportation Center.
Route 13 Trolley provides access to the southern half of the corridor
via Elmwood Avenue and Island Avenue.
Route 108 Bus provides frequent service along several streets that
adjacent to the trail corridor, including Church Lane, Elmwood Avenue,
Route 116 Bus, which enters the study area at Church Lane and
runs along the Cobbs Creek Parkway and Island Avenue, provides limited
service between 69th Street Terminal and the Eastwick Postal Facility.
SEPTA’s Elmwood Depot is located on the east side of Island Avenue near
Elmwood Avenue. While not part of an active route, the trolley tracks along
Island Avenue between Woodland Avenue and Elmwood Avenue are used for
routing vehicles to and from the depot.
Also in close proximity to the study area is Eastwick Station, which serves
SEPTA’s Airport Regional Rail Line and is located approximately 1/2 mile to the
southeast of the 84th Street/Lindbergh Boulevard intersection. Opportunities to
improve bicycle and pedestrian connections to this station are currently being
investigated through a separate eﬀ ort.
The Study Team performed a comprehensive environmental analysis of the
proposed trail corridor concurrently with the trail planning eﬀ ort to identify
environmental resources and constraints that could potentially inﬂ uence the trail
alignment. The following section describes the environmental analysis process
A ﬁ eld view of the trail corridor was conducted on July 28, 2011 to identify
potential wetland areas. The distance to the eastern bank of Cobbs Creek from
the trail varies greatly over the length of the trail from approximately 50 feet
at several locations to over 1,000 feet east of the Clearview Landﬁ ll. Within the
study area, the banks of Cobbs Creek are generally steep to vertical at some
locations due to bank erosion. Sediments in the creek varied but included silt,
sand, and cobble. Silt and sand bars were present throughout the study area
in the bottom of the creek. The hydrology in Cobbs Creek is ﬂ ashy due to the
highly impervious and urbanized watershed. However, pools and long runs are
present in Cobbs Creek throughout the study area.
Potential wetland areas were identiﬁ ed using readily available data sources in
combination with ﬁ eld observation of vegetation and other indicators. Available
data sources included the National Wetlands Inventory (NWI) and United States
Geological Survey (USGS) soils mapping, while ﬁ eld observations considered
topographical position and visual evidence of hydrology. Several wetlands were
identiﬁ ed in the vicinity of the proposed trail and added to the project base
mapping (a detailed memorandum describing these wetland areas is included in
Appendix C). The wetland areas identiﬁ ed should be considered preliminary and
are not appropriate for permit-level documentation.
The trail alignment alternatives were screened and revised based on the
preliminary wetland determination to avoid direct impacts to these identiﬁ ed
This task included a preliminary assessment of the habitats occurring along
the proposed trail corridor, along with a Pennsylvania Natural Diversity Index
(PNDI) database search. The PNDI receipt indicated four (4) species of concern
under the PADCNR jurisdiction and four (4) species of concern under the
PFBC jurisdiction as potential conﬂ icts. A preliminary habitat assessment
was conducted on July 28, 2011 to investigate the PNDI results. The site visit
Cobbs Creek is currently degraded by a variety of factors including stormwater
runoﬀ from a highly urban watershed and a variety of non-native and invasive
plant species along its banks. However, it provides aquatic habitat for a variety
of wildlife species including warm water ﬁ sh, frogs, turtles, and birds. Cobbs
Creek ﬂ ows into Darby Creek which ﬂ ows into the JHNWR. These creeks and
the wildlife refuge are known to support a variety of rare, threatened and
endangered species in addition to a variety of more common wildlife species.
Turtle species observed in Cobbs Creek during the ﬁ eld visit included eastern
painted turtle, common snapping turtle, and red-eared slider. Cobbs Creek and
Darby Creek are also known to support the eastern red-bellied turtle. Anuran
species were not observed during the preliminary habitat assessment.
The trail corridor is located in a heavily urbanized and developed portion of
Philadelphia, and several of the proposed alternatives traverse mowed lawns
and areas of early successional woodlands. The woodland habitats within the
study area are dominated by species tolerant of urban conditions and invasive
herbaceous species (primarily Japanese knotweed and mugwort) are prevalent
along many stretches of the corridor. While no target species were observed
during the ﬁ eld assessment, one sweet-bay magnolia and two willow oaks were
The trail alignment alternatives were screened and revised based on the
preliminary habitat assessment to avoid potential habitat areas. Based on the
habitat assessment and preliminary trail alternatives, CRA submitted initial
consultation documentation to both the Pennsylvania Fish and Boat Commission
(PFBC) and Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources
(PADCNR) for guidance on further required study. In response, PFBC issued a
letter in December 2011 clearing the alternatives of further environmental work
related to wildlife, while PADCNR issued a clearance letter in February 2012
indicating “no anticipated impacts” to plant species (both letters are included in
Based on an initial screening of the corridor and information from the 2007
Hazardous Waste Screening Study, the following sites were targeted for further
study as part of this eﬀ ort:
Heinz Wildlife Refuge/Tinicum Marsh, Lindbergh Blvd. & 86th Street,
Sunoco Service Station, Cobbs Creek Parkway & 70th Street, Philadelphia,
70th & Kingsessing Trailer, 70th Street and Kingsessing Blvd., Philadelphia,
Alto Sign, 2032-2038 South 71st Street, Philadelphia, PA
Clearview Landﬁ ll, 83rd & Buist Ave, Darby Township, PA 19023
80th & Mars Place (Eastwick Recreational Park), 80th & Mars, Philadelphia,
SEPTA Elmwood Depot, 7311 Elmwood Ave, Philadelphia, PA 19142
Tony Kings Exxon, 2501 Island Ave, Philadelphia, PA
Merit Oil Company of PA Inc., 2450 Island Road, Philadelphia, PA 19153
The Study Team completed a ﬁ le review in coordination with the Pennsylvania
Department of Environmental Protection (PADEP) to determine the extent of
available information related to the selected sites listed above. Based on the
additional information obtained from PADEP, the Clearview Landﬁ ll was identiﬁ ed
as the only site with the potential to inﬂ uence the proposed trail alignment. The
landﬁ ll is part of the Lower Darby Creek Area (LDCA) Superfund Site and was
listed on USEPA’s National Priorities List (NPL) in 2001.
Coordination with USEPA Region 3 staﬀ was maintained throughout the project
to follow the status of the superfund site (minutes from the initial July 2011
meeting are included in Appendix A). During the project, the USEPA published a
Remedial Investigation (RI) for the site, which was reviewed to ascertain potential
While the RI report did not specify a remedial action or identify potential impact
limits, USEPA staﬀ indicated that impacts from the remedial action could extend
into Eastwick Park and aﬀ ect the area where the existing trail is located. For
instance, if the landﬁ ll were to be capped, the resulting ﬁ ll lines could change the
topography of areas in the park adjacent to the landﬁ ll. USEPA staﬀ also noted
that the future site remediation would likely allow parts of the landﬁ ll to be used
Based on consultation with the USEPA and coordination with the project Steering
Committee, the following approach to the proposed trail alignment in the
vicinity of the Clearview Landﬁ ll site is recommended:
Develop Conceptual Design plans for the trail segment through Eastwick
Develop an interim on-road bikeway alignment through the Eastwick
neighborhood as a near-term alternative to the oﬀ -road trail segment
Continue to monitor the status of USEPA’s eﬀ orts during future stages of
Potential Trail Corridor Behind Evantine Design
The complexity of the trail corridor and the presence of numerous physical
constraints led to the development and evaluation of a number of alignments.
An initial set of trail alternatives based on those presented in the 2007 Feasibility
Study was supplemented with additional alternatives to provide a range
of options in key areas. The development of alternatives considered both
short-term and long-term alignments for each segment as appropriate. Each
alternative was developed in a suﬃ
cient level of detail to determine potential
impacts. A brief description of the alternatives is provided below by segment:
The alternatives analysis eﬀ ort in this area focused on a combination of oﬀ and
on-road alternatives. Oﬀ -road alternatives includes an alignment that enters
Delaware County and then crosses back to Philadelphia on a pedestrian bridge,
a tunnel beneath the CSX rail embankment, and a boardwalk along the existing
abutment of the CSX bridge over Cobbs Creek. On-road options included an
alignment along Cobbs Creek Parkway and several alignments through the
adjacent neighborhood via 70th Street, 71st Street, and Greenway Avenue.
Options for this segment included an alignment that approaches Cobbs Creek
via Glenmore Avenue and then runs along the edge of the Evantine property,
and a second alignment located further from the creek that connects to the
Both near-term and long-term alignments were developed for this segment. On-
going environmental work by the USEPA at the Clearview Landﬁ ll site prompted
the alignment through Eastwick Park to be considered as a long-term option.
The near-term option was an on-road route through the Eastwick neighborhood
that connects with 84th Street. Multiple options were also considered in the area
near the Cibotti Recreation Center and from 82nd Street to 84th Street.
From 84th Street to the JHNWR, potential options included an on-road alignment
along Lindbergh Boulevard and several oﬀ -road alignments that would cross
84th Street at a new location and enter JHNWR to the west of Lindbergh
Proposed Trail Corridor for Segment B
The engineering issues and environmental/physical features associated with
each alignment were primary factors in determining their feasibility. For the on-
c analysis was performed at key intersections to compare
existing conditions with proposed conditions and determine potential impacts
were presented to representatives from the Philadelphia Streets Department
and PennDOT District 6-0 at individual stakeholder meetings, and the proposed
concepts were retained, revised, or eliminated based on their feedback (meeting
minutes are included in Appendix A).
Primary screening considerations for the oﬀ -road alternatives included the
regulatory implications of new structures or ﬁ ll in the Cobbs Creek ﬂ oodplain,
anticipated costs of structures and associated maintenance, and potential
impacts to environmental resources including wetlands, habitat areas, and
hazardous waste areas. In consultation with the Steering Committee and other
stakeholders, the Project Team eliminated alternatives that were not feasible or
Additional quantitative and qualitative factors during the evaluation included:
Quality of experience for trail users
The technical alternatives analysis evaluation process reduced the initial range of
feasible alternatives to a preliminary reﬁ ned set of alternatives. The reﬁ ned set of
alternatives was then presented to the Steering Committee for a ﬁ nal evaluation.
After discussing and implementing several modiﬁ cations, a proposed trail
Planning and conceptual design of the proposed alignment was based on the
most current bicycle and pedestrian design guidelines, including the AASHTO
Guide for Planning, Design, and Operation of Bicycle Facilities (including NCHRP’s
2010 update), the Manual on Uniform Traﬃ
PennDOT Design Manual 2, and guidelines from the East Cost Greenway Alliance.
Oﬀ -road portions of the trail were designed as a minimum 12-foot wide, bi-
directional, paved shared-use path similar to the existing Cobbs Creek Trail north
of 70th Street, while portions adjacent to roadways or located in constrained
areas were designed with a minimum width of 10 feet.
The proposed trail alignment shown in Figure 4 was
shaped by data collection, concept development,
alternatives analysis, and stakeholder input between
June 2011 and July 2012. The following section describes
individual segments and key areas in detail. Within this
section, the term “trail” refers to primarily oﬀ -road portions
of the facility while “sidepath” refers to portions that are
Beginning at the existing terminus of the Cobbs Creek Trail (CCT), the proposed trail would extend south between the creek and the Cobbs Creek Parkway on land owned
by PP&R. The trail would then wind around the west side of the Blue Bell Inn before intersecting with Woodland Avenue. Key areas along this segment include:
The existing trail terminates at a curb ramp on the north side of the intersection.
Trail users would cross the west side of the intersection to access the new portion
of the trail and continue south on the high ground adjacent to the Cobbs Creek
Parkway. A 6-foot wide grass buﬀ er area is proposed to separate the trail from
The proposed concept improves the intersection geometry to accommodate
a new crossing of Cobbs Creek Parkway on the south side of the intersection.
This crossing will provide better access to the trail from neighborhoods to the
east and make it easier for trail users to access the Dunkin Donuts at the corner
of 70th Street. The Church Lane approach would be reconﬁ gured so that the
eastbound right-turn move onto southbound Cobbs Creek Parkway operates
concurrently with the northbound Cobbs Creek Parkway split phase. The
eastbound right-turn would then be stopped with a red arrow during east-west
through movements to allow for a protected pedestrian phase. Preliminary
c analysis indicates that vehicle delay for the overall intersection would
decrease in the proposed condition (results are included in Appendix B).
The concept plan also indicates potential areas to handle stormwater
management. Portions of the paved islands could be candidates for pervious
materials or plantings to encourage inﬁ ltration. Existing grassy areas could also
be transformed into rain gardens or simply enhanced via increased plantings.
CSX Bridge over Cobbs Creek Parkway

text.i: CSX Bridge over Cobbs Creek Parkway

page.text: Proceeding south, the existing CSX bridge over the parkway presents an
obstacle, as there is currently not enough room to accommodate a sidewalk or
trail beneath the bridge. The proposed solution is to reduce each travel lane to
10 feet, shift the lanes to the east side of the structure, replace the northbound
guide rail with a concrete barrier connected directly to the stone abutment, and
create a 6-foot wide shared-use path through the bridge that is separated from
the soutbound travel lane by a concrete barrier. Traﬃ
north of the bridge at 70th Street and to the south of the bridge at Greenway
Avenue are important elements of the plan as they would help to reduce
automobile speeds through the bridge area.

text.b: Figure 6: CSX Bridge over Cobbs Creek Parkway
Figure 7: Greenway Avenue/Cobbs Creek Parkway Intersection

page.text: A new pedestrian crossing at Greenway Avenue would beneﬁ t the project by improving access from the local neighborhood and calming traﬃ
Parkway. The existing park area would be extended and a new island would be created to channelize the traﬃ
c lanes and provide a pedestrian refuge area. Similar to the
70th Street concept, it is recommended that the island areas be designed to enhance stormwater management via rain gardens, plantings, or other pervious treatments.
South of the Woodland Avenue crossing, the proposed shared-use path is located along the west side of Island Avenue in the sidewalk area. The sidepath alignment
continues south beneath the Amtrak railroad bridge until just past the PennDOT license center, where it turns west and runs adjacent to the parking lot on a City-owned
drainage ROW. At the end of the parking lot, the trail traverses a Redevelopment Authority parcel and connects with Wheeler Street. From there, the trail continues along
the Wheeler “paper street” ROW until Claymont Street, where it veers away from the roadway and towards the creek. The trail then runs roughly parallel to the creek on the
same City drainage ROW before reconnecting with Elmwood Avenue at 77th Street. This segment includes the following key areas:
A curb extension at the northwest corner in front of the Blue Bell Inn would
provide additional room for bicyclists and pedestrians waiting to make the
crossing, while a matching curb extension on the northeast corner would
provide room for an enhanced trolley stop. South of the intersection, a 10-foot
wide shared-use path would use the sidewalk area on the west side of Island
Avenue. A 4-foot wide grass buﬀ er area is proposed to separate the sidepath

text.b: Figure 10: Amtrak Bridge over Island Avenue

page.text: The proposed alignment features a 10-foot wide shared-use path beneath the
Amtrak Bridge in the sidewalk area on the west side of Island Avenue. A 2-foot
wide buﬀ er between the bridge abutment and sidepath is needed to provide
a minimum vertical clearance of 7.5 feet between bicyclists and the archway. A
3-foot wide buﬀ er is also proposed to separate the sidepath from the nearest
southbound travel lane. Both of these buﬀ er areas should be textured and/or
painted to encourage riders to stay within the sidepath limits.
From Elmwood Avenue, the proposed alignment runs south along the west side of 77th Street as a shared-use path in the sidewalk area. Just south of the Cibotti
Recreation Center playground, the sidepath would turn away from the street and run west between the recreation center and Penrose Elementary School. The sidepath
would continue on the north side of Motivation High School and then connect with 78th Street, which is recommended as a trailhead location. On-going environmental
work by the USEPA at the Clearview Landﬁ ll site makes further development of a new trail through Eastwick Park infeasible until remediation and site-regrading are
completed. Therefore, both near-term and long-term alignments were developed for the stretch between 78th Street and 84th Street. The near-term alignment is an on-
road route through the neighborhood that eventually connects with 84th Street, while the long-term alignment would create a new trail through Eastwick Park.
The corner of 77th Street and Elmwood Avenue would be reconﬁ gured to
create a dedicated parking area for the ballﬁ elds. This concept not only reduces
the amount of impervious area and provides additional space for landscaping
but also provides additional space for bicyclists and pedestrians. The sidepath
would continue south as a 15-foot wide shared-use area along the west side
of 77th Street. As there is a signiﬁ cant amount of activity in this area, especially
during baseball games and other events, the sidepath should be designed to
reduce potential conﬂ icts with people walking to the recreation center or being
dropped-oﬀ at the curb. Potential treatments include signage and striping that
encourage lower bicycle speeds and promote awareness of the path.
Just south of the Cibotti Recreation Center playground, the sidepath would head
west and return to a 12-foot wide oﬀ -road trail conﬁ guration located between
the recreation center and Penrose Elementary School. Several trees and the
chain link fence will need to be relocated to accommodate the path. A physical
separation will also be needed between the trail and the playground, which
could be provided by a low fence, landscaping, or some other treatment.
The proposed alignment for this section of the East Coast Greenway would be an
oﬀ -road trail through Eastwick Park; however, the timing is complicated by the
USEPA’s on-going study of the Clearview Landﬁ ll. USEPA has indicated that the
future remedial action for the landﬁ ll has the potential to change the topography
within Eastwick Park, which would consequently aﬀ ect any alignment that is
developed for the trail. As a result, a conceptual trail alignment was developed to
inform future discussions with USEPA regarding alignment and cost; however, it
will likely change based on the outcome of the environmental process.
Eastwick Park currently features an 8-foot wide walking path between 78th
Street and 82nd Street, although large stretches are in disrepair and the overall
geometry was not designed to meet current trail standards. Rather than modify
the existing path, a new 12-foot wide trail is proposed to meet minimum design
standards. Except for two shared segments near 78th Street and Angelo Place,
the new trail would run parallel to the existing walking path but on a new
alignment. The new trail would extend south of 82nd Street via a City-owned
parcel to connect with the dead-end at Chelwynde Avenue. Figure 14 shows a
rendering of the proposed trail near 78th Street, while conceptual design plans
for the entire trail alignment through Eastwick Park are included in Appendix D.
Shared Lane Marking on 15th Street in Philadelphia
In the near-term, the proposed trailhead at 78th Street would mark the end of
the oﬀ -road trail segment. From there, the trail would transition to an on-road
facility comprised of signage and striping on neighborhood streets. Shared-lane
markings, commonly referred to as “sharrows,” would be used to indicate the best
lateral placement for bicyclists and also help alert motorists to the presence of a
bicycle route. The on-road route would be striped and signed along 78th Street,
Buist Avenue, 83rd Street, and Chelwynde Avenue. At the end of Chelwynde
Avenue, the route would transition to an oﬀ -road trail that begins Segment D.
This segment begins at the end of Chelwynde Avenue at the nexus of the near-term and long-term Segment C alignments. From there, the proposed oﬀ -road trail
continues east along the 84th Street right-of-way until the intersection with Lindbergh Boulevard. The trail crosses 84th Street on the west side of the intersection and then
continue south along the west side of Lindbergh Boulevard on a new shared-use path that is buﬀ ered from the street by a planted bio-swale.
The proposed concept replaces the 84th Street eastbound right-turn lane with
a landscaped area. In addition to reducing the amount of impervious area, this
would shorten the pedestrian crossing and provide an opportunity to create
an enhanced “gateway” to the JHNWR. Bicycle ramps should also be provided
at each corner of the intersection to transition bicyclists from riding in the bike
lanes to using the crosswalks as a pedestrian, and the double right turn lane from
southbound Lindbergh Boulevard should be modiﬁ ed to have overhead signal
control per the latest MUTCD standards. The new signal location will discourage
motorists from turning right-on-red, while an enlarged median island will provide
c analysis indicates that, due to very low volumes, removal
of the right-turn lane will have negligible eﬀ ects on traﬃ
are included in Appendix B). However, the cycle length will likely need to be
increased to 100 or 120 seconds to accommodate the proposed pedestrian
clearance interval. Lengthening the eastbound 84th Street left-turn lanes to
provide additional queue space could also be investigated as a potential way to
LENGTH BETWEEN CURB BREAKS TO BE DETERMINED IN DESIGN
The existing 60-foot wide cartway along Lindbergh Boulevard presents an
opportunity to reclaim part of the roadway to accommodate the trail. The
proposed concept would provide room for a new 12-foot wide buﬀ ered shared-
use path along the west side of Lindbergh Boulevard while simultaneously
reducing the amount of impervious area. The path would be separated from
the roadway by a 10-foot wide curbed bio-swale comprised of gravel, soil, and
plantings. At 86th Street, the shared-use path would transition from Lindbergh
Boulevard into the JHNWR. Figure 17 shows a rendering of the proposed
Several residents expressed concerns at the community meetings about security
and asked if the trail would be lit and what hours of the day it would be open. At
this phase of the project, the Steering Committee consensus was to only keep
the trail open during daylight hours (i.e. from “dusk until dawn”), which is a similar
condition to trails in other parts of Philadelphia. Lighting would be provided for
segments along the street via existing roadway lighting, but oﬀ -road segments
would not be designed with new lighting (except for the portion within Eastwick
Park). Signage, gating, security cameras, and other security features are potential
treatments for the oﬀ -road segments. Lighting and security measures will need
to be addressed in future design phases.
The scope of this project included developing Conceptual Design plans for
Segments C and D, which covers the trail corridor from 77th Street to the JHNWR
(plans are included in Appendix D). These plans, which are shown at a 1”= 30’
scale, were developed with the expectation that City of Philadelphia and PA
DCNR - Community Conservation and Partnerships Program design standards
will govern ﬁ nal design for oﬀ -road segments and PennDOT and City of
Philadelphia design standards will govern ﬁ nal design for on-road segments.
A preliminary cost estimate was developed for the proposed Cobbs Creek
Connector Trail alignment. The estimate includes construction and materials
costs, engineering/professional design costs, construction management/
inspection costs, and a 20% contingency. A summary of the estimate is included
in Figure 18, while the full estimate is included in Appendix E.
Phasing and implementation of the overall alignment will be based on several
factors including the availability of design and construction funding. Two
stages for Segment C reﬂ ect the trail options before and after the Eastwick Park
• Near-term: Includes the segment along 77th Street and the on-road
• Long-term: Includes the additional cost of a trail segment through
Eastwick Park, but does not include any environmental remediation costs
Through this study, the Clean Air Council advanced project development for
approximately two miles of proposed trail between the existing northern
terminus of the Cobbs Creek Trail at 70th Street and the John Heinz National
Wildlife Refuge at the southern end. The study identiﬁ ed a number of alternative
alignments, evaluated the feasibility of these alternatives, recommended a
proposed trail alignment, and completed Conceptual Design for Segments C/D.
The process to bring the entire Cobbs Creek Trail Connector into use includes the
Complete Conceptual Design for Segments A/B
Identify funding for Engineering Design for all segments
Initiate and complete Engineering Design for all segments
Identify funding for Construction for all segments
Initiate and complete Construction for all segments
Clean Air Council intends to maintain responsibility for this project through
Engineering Design. Once Engineering Design is underway, and depending on
the progress of each segment, the Council may pursue construction funding
for segments individually or all at once. The following provides a more detailed
breakdown of the next project phases by segment:
Partial funding has been secured through a grant from PADEP’s Coastal
Zone Management program to complete both Conceptual Design and
Engineering Design for these two segments as a single project. Additional
funding sources are necessary to cover the balance of anticipated costs prior
The near-term on-road alignment for Segment C will be implemented
in coordination with the Philadelphia City Planning Commission (PCPC),
ce of Transportation and Utilities (MOTU), and the Philadelphia
Streets Department. This alignment will need to be coordinated with the
Philadelphia Pedestrian & Bicycle Plan and existing bicycle routes.
The long-term alignment for Segment C will be advanced in coordination
with USEPA’s continued work on the Clearview Landﬁ ll site. Clean Air Council
and Philadelphia Parks & Recreation (PP&R) will continue to coordinate with
USEPA to make sure the future trail is a consideration in the planning and
design of the landﬁ ll remediation and restoration.
Funding is secured to complete Engineering Design for Segment D through
an FTA Sarbanes Grant. A Request for Proposal will be issued in the short term
for a consultant team to complete Engineering Design.
Clean Air Council will continue to reach out to stakeholders so that all parties
are involved in the development of the Cobbs Creek Connector Trail. In the
immediate future, this includes coordinating with PennDOT District 6-0 regarding
Engineering Design for Segment D. This will also include working with the
Philadelphia Redevelopment Authority (PRA) to transfer necessary parcels along
the trail alignment to PP&R. Finally, the surrounding community will continue
to be involved through additional public meetings where progress can be
presented and feedback received as the trail design moves forward.

text.b: Stakeholder Meeting with USEPA, Region 3, Superfund (July 18, 2011)

page.text: Coordination meeting with USEPA, Region 3, Superfund
Urban met with Josh Barber of the EPA on Monday, July 18, 2011 at the EPA Region 3
office to discuss the Clearview Landfill Superfund site. A summary of major discussion
Josh provided an approximate schedule of the next steps following release of the
A Feasibility Study that is currently underway will evaluate cleanup and
containment alternatives and provide recommendations for remediation strategies.
Completion of the Feasibility Study is anticipated for December 2011.
The Feasibility Study will be followed by a Proposed Plan, which is followed by a
Record of Decision (ROD) for the Proposed Action. The ROD is anticipated in
April 2013; however, if the Proposed Action is over $25 million it needs to be
approved by the EPA Board. This can add 4-5 months to the process.
Following the ROD, the EPA will need to negotiate any Potentially Responsible
Parties (PRPs). The negotiation period could take a year or more. While no PRPs
have yet been identified, this existing owner may be a consideration.
The next step is engineering design of the Proposed Action (Remedial Design/
RD), which would likely last for one year. This would be followed by
construction. Josh anticipates that the earliest start would be 2014 for RD and
To date, no funding source has been identified for the eventual remedial action. The
current study is being funded by a line-item in the EPA's budget. At this point, Josh
anticipates that the remediation will be broken into stages and incrementally funded.
The remedial action would likely extend into Eastwick Park and could affect the area
where the existing trail is located. Since the landfill would likely be capped, the resulting
fill lines would likely change the topography of some of the areas adjacent to the landfill.
Terraces would probably be used to grade the landfill itself. Josh noted that the EPA is
required to replace in-kind any existing features that are affected by the remedial action.
Once the landfill is remediated, the site could potentially be used for recreational
purposes. The EPA will collaborate with the property owner and nearby community in
an attempt to make the remediation conducive to the new use.
Josh outlined his thoughts on moving forward with trail planning and design in this area:
He said that a likely containment measure would consist of a cap/cover over the
landfill that extends into portions of the park. However, he noted that it would be
reasonable for Urban/CAC to continue planning and designing the trail
independent of the landfill remediation. If in the worst case the constructed trail
was affected by the EPA's remedial action, it would be replaced in-kind by the
Another option is to investigate using an interim on-road bikeway alignment until
the remedial action is implemented; however, this is not consistent with the goals
More information on the nature and extents of the remediation alternatives will be
available once the Feasibility Study is completed. If possible, Josh will try to
provide Urban with more detailed information prior to completion of the FS.
This is a summary of the approximate timeline for site remediation:
Proposed Plan and Record of Decision

text.b: Stakeholder Meeting with Philadelphia Street Department (September 16, 2011)

page.text: A coordination meeting with the City of Philadelphia Streets Department for the Cobbs
Creek Connector Trail project was held on Friday, September 16, 2011 at the Clean Air
Council office. John described the alternatives currently under consideration for
Segments A through D. A summary of major discussion items is listed below:
Cobbs Creek Pkwy/70th St/Church St Concepts: Charles was generally
supportive of the two concepts developed for this intersection, but suggested the
Replace the parking area in front of Dunkin Donuts with a loading area
Change the EB Church Street approach to show separate right, thru, and
Explore the concept of eliminating the center islands on 70th Street to
Alt. A1: Charles agreed that the signalized, single bi-directional lane concept
through the CSX bridge is not feasible based on traffic and safety issues. He was
supportive of the sidewalk concept, which narrows the travel lanes and replaces
the guiderail with barriers to create room for a 5-6 foot sidewalk. He suggested
narrowing the lanes from 10.5 to 10 feet to create a wider sidewalk.
Alt. A5: Charles was supportive of the proposed cross-section options along 70th
Street and 71st Street. Along Greenway Avenue, he said that a multi-use path
using the sidewalk zone is not a viable option due to the adjacent residences. As
an alternative, he suggested creating an option that narrows the cartway to 34 feet
and uses the extra 10 feet to create a multi-use path adjacent to the existing
Cobbs Creek Pkwy/Greenway Ave Concept: Charles was supportive of the
crossing concept at this intersection, but suggested the following modifications:
Widen the median refuge island on Cobbs Creek Parkway to 8 feet
Add a 4 foot wide median on Cobbs Creek Parkway from Woodland
Avenue to the proposed crossing location
Show back-in angled parking along the one-way section of Cobbs Creek
Identify pedestrian-actuated rectangular rapid flashing beacons (RRFB's)
as a candidate treatment at this location, along with an over-the-roadway
flashing beacon. He noted that PennDOT may ultimately decide to install
a pedestrian-actuated or full signal instead of the beacons.
Charles confirmed that trucks are not allowed on the Cobbs Creek Parkway
between 58th Street to the north and Woodland Avenue to the south. SEPTA bus
routes are exempted from the prohibition (Route 116 operates on this stretch).
Woodland Ave/Island Ave Concept: Charles said that a two-approach, diagonal
pedestrian crossing of the intersection is not feasible due to its impacts on the
signal cycle length. He noted that this intersection is very congested. He
supported the bumpout and multi-use trail elements of the intersection concept
plan and offered the following comments:
Vadim Fleysh with the Streets Dept. is currently managing a project that
will install an exclusive trolley turning phase at this signal. The affected
trolley movements will be the NB right-turn onto Woodland Ave and the
EB right-turn onto Island Ave. Charles noted that Vadim has a
SYNCHRO model for this intersection and said that the AM volumes may
be more critical than the PM volumes.
Charles suggested decreasing the width of the bumpouts from 8 feet to 5-6
feet and checking for underground utilities in the bumpout areas
Alt. B1-2: Charles said that the roadside of Island Street between Woodland
Avenue and Glenmore Avenue is an acceptable environment for a multi-use path
using the sidewalk zone. Under the Amtrak bridge, he said that an 8-foot vertical
pedestrian clearance should be sufficient and suggested the possibility of lowering
the sidewalk elevation to gain additional clearance.
Alt. D4: Charles said that the on-road alignment along Buist, 83rd, and
Chelwynde Streets is a candidate for sharrows due to low traffic volumes and
speeds. He agreed that the width of Lindbergh Boulevard south of 84th Street
will provide ample room for a buffered cycle track.
84th Street/Lindbergh Boulevard Intersection: Charles said that a mid-block
crossing approximately 500 feet west of Lindbergh Boulevard may not have a
significant impact on traffic if it were timed to work with the adjacent signal. He
noted that PennDOT has not approved the HAWK pedestrian beacon to be used
state-wide, so the crossing would need a pedestrian-actuated signal instead
(although he noted that the pedestrian beacon minimum volume warrants might
still apply). He also agreed that the existing traffic signal at 84th Street/Lindbergh
Boulevard was a viable crossing location and would likely be more cost-effective.
For the alternatives affecting state-owned roadways (Cobbs Creek Parkway and
Island Avenue), Charles said that PennDOT will also need to review and
ultimately approve of the proposed concepts. Charles mentioned Lou Belmont as
a potential PennDOT contact for coordination on this project.
As a result of the meeting discussion, the following actions will be taken:
Add parcel lines and key property owners to concept plans
Contact Vadim Fleysh to obtain SYNCHRO model
Setup a coordination meeting with PennDOT
It is believed that the enclosed represents an accurate description of the major events that
transpired at this meeting. Your notification of any errors or omissions is essential, as the
foregoing is intended to be part of the record, and is the basis upon which we will
One Parkway Building, 10th Floor Fairmount Conference Room
The second Steering Committee meeting for the Cobbs Creek Connector Trail project
was held on Monday, September 19, 2011 at the Philadelphia Parks & Recreation
(PP&R) office. John presented the alternatives currently under consideration for
Segments A through D. A summary of major discussion items is listed below:
Rob mentioned that PWD is currently working on a new design for the grassy
area at the NE corner of the Woodland Ave/Island Ave intersection. He will
provide Urban with a contact at PWD to obtain these plans.
Segment A: Rob said that PP&R does not support the structure and tunnel
alternatives (A2, A3, & A4) due to potential security issues and future
maintenance costs. The group agreed to retain alternatives A1 and A5 but to
remove the others from consideration. It was noted that even if A1 becomes the
preferred alternative, elements of A5 should still be considered to connect the
neighborhood with the trail (perhaps as part of a future PWD project).
Segment B: The group supports both alternatives at this point. B1 is attractive
because it is more wooded and closer to the creek, but potential issues include its
placement on private property and areas of steep slopes. Dennis Winters will
reach out to Evantine to determine their view on this alignment. B2 has less
feasibility issues and provides better connections to the adjacent neighborhood,
but it will involve coordination with RDA because it runs adjacent to and through
some of their parcels. Urban will follow up with RDA to confirm ownership and
future plans for these parcels. Jeannette noted that Leigh Jones is the contact at
Segment C: The group was favorable of the proposed alignment through the
Cibotti Rec Center and Eastwick Park. The baseball field at the rec center is
heavily used, so it will be important to avoid impacts to operations. Rob will
share the concept plans with senior staff at PP&R to obtain feedback on the
Path alignment through Cibotti Rec Center (relocation of fence; re-grading
of slope; impact on ballfields; potential trailhead/parking off 78th Street)
Path alignment through Eastwick Park adjacent to existing trail (parallel
alignments for ECG and local walking path; future plans for chess/seating
area and park in general; potential environmental issues)
New path extending from Eastwick Park to 84th/Lindbergh (relationship
with Citywide driveway and potential environmental issues)
Segment D: It was agreed that D3 should be removed from consideration based
on input from Gary Stolz at the JHNWR, who does not favor this alignment. The
group agreed that D2 is the preferred option because it keeps the trail on a natural
alignment and avoids neighborhood impacts. However, the viability of option D2
is very dependent on the USEPA's plans for remediating the Clearview Landfill
site. PP&R, CAC, and PEC will be meeting with USEPA on September 26 to
discuss this issue. Where D2 intersections with 84th Street, Charles said that he
prefers a new mid-block crossing instead of using the existing crossing at 84th
and Lindbergh. The trail would then head east to meet the 84th/Lindbergh
intersection. Regardless of the crossing location, the preferred alignment will
utilize the stretch of Lindbergh Boulevard south of 84th Street.
CAC is in the process of scheduling a community meeting for the northern half of
the corridor on Wednesday, October 19th. They will attempt to schedule a second
community meeting for the southern half of the corridor on the following
Wednesday, October 26th. It was agreed that the graphics would read more
clearly to the public if the remaining alternatives are renamed in a logical manner.
As a result of the meeting discussion, the following actions will be taken:
Follow up with PWD to obtain plans near Woodland Ave;
Follow up with RDA to confirm ownership/future plans for
Meet with Evantine to discuss alternative B1
Discuss trail alternatives on PP&R land with senior staff
It is believed that the enclosed represents an accurate description of the major events that
transpired at this meeting. Your notification of any errors or omissions is essential, as the
foregoing is intended to be part of the record, and is the basis upon which we will
A coordination meeting with CSX for the Cobbs Creek Connector Trail project was held
on Thursday, September 29, 2011 at the Clean Air Council office. John described the
alternatives currently under consideration for Segment A. A summary of major
Bill's opinion is that the viaduct (A2) and tunnel (A4) alternatives are not viable
options because of potential visibility and security issues, along with their
relatively high cost and complexity. He noted that both alternatives would require
a substantial amount of engineering review by CSX as they have the potential to
affect the load-bearing capacity of adjacent structures.
Bill's overall opinion is that the sidewalk alternative (A1) under the CSX bridge
would not present problems to CSX, primarily because it does not alter the load-
bearing capacity of the abutments and does not increase access to the railbed. Bill
noted that CSX currently does not have any plans to replace or modify either of
the bridges in this corridor. Bill does not believe that CSX has any as-built plans
for the CSX bridge over Cobbs Creek Parkway, but he will check internally.
CSX has contracted with AECOM to provide design reviews and Alanna
Strohecker is the current project manager at AECOM. Bill asked for JPG's of the
before and after condition for A1, which he will circulate internally with AECOM
Bill noted that we may want to consider adding lighting under the bridge for A1.
The group agreed that it would be a good idea to provide wider passing and rest
areas on each side of the bridge for A1.
When this project goes to engineering design, several levels of review will likely
Execute a "Preliminary Engineering Agreement" with CSX for
AECOM's review (the cost of AECOM's review time should be factored
PennDOT Review Process: PennDOT will likely require an Engineering
Railroad Analysis and a Construction Agreement for CM/CI; however,
flag protection will probably not be needed during construction.
Pennsylvania Public Utilities Commission (PUC) Coordination: Bill
was not sure if this project would trigger PUC coordination, as it does not
affect the actual rail line but may affect the bridge abutments. This should
be determined prior to engineering design so as to account for the potential
cost and time of PUC coordination.
As a result of the meeting discussion, the following actions will be taken:
Forward JPG's of before/after condition for A1
Circulate A1 concept internally for preliminary comments
Check on the availability of as-built plans for the CSX
Clean Air Council and Urban Engineers will be hosting a Community Open
October 19th in the Community Room of the PPaschalville Branch
of the Free Library at 6942 Woodland Avenue from 4
This will be an opportunity to discuss the planned Cobbs Creek Connector
Trail with the design team and the lead advocates. The bike and multi-use
trail will run from 70th and Cobbs Creek Parkway where the existing trail
ends, to the John Heinz Wildlife Refuge. Community members have the
chance to see what preliminary plans have been made, ask questions, and
give their input on route options and design of the trail.
Clean Air Council and Urban Engineers would like as many community
members as possible to come out to this event! Stop in for as little or as long
Paschalville Branch of the Free Library
Meeting from 4 PM to library closing at 7 PM
7000 Geerdes Boulevard, King of Prussia, PA
A coordination meeting for the Cobbs Creek Connector Trail project was held on
Thursday, January 26, 2012 at the PennDOT District 6-0 office. Nick Rogers provided
an overview of the project background, while John Federico described the alternatives
currently under consideration for Segments A through D. A summary of major
discussion items is listed below by Segment:
Cobbs Creek Pkwy/70th St/Church Lane Intersection (A1/A2): PennDOT
was supportive of the intersection concepts developed for alternatives A1 and A2
Use of both the yellow and red intervals as part of the pedestrian clearance
time will be a decision for the City Street Department. PennDOT
preference is to only use the yellow interval. Charles Denny said that his
general preference would be to use both yellow and red intervals if it
For WB Church Lane, stripe two travel lanes through the intersection and
then show a lane drop immediately after passing the Cobbs Creek.
ADA ramps for the trail will have to be wider than a typical ramp for a
sidewalk. Where the trail is transitioning to an on-road bike lane, a
During the next phase of design, investigate the possibility of changing the
geometry slightly to allow for concurrent phases instead of split phases.
Keep in mind that if an existing crosswalk is to be removed or changed, a
pedestrian study will be required by PennDOT.
CSX Bridge (A1): PennDOT was supportive of the proposed concept for A1
under the CSX bridge, which features 10-foot travel lanes, and a 6-foot sidewalk.
Ashwin Patel suggested retaining the edge striping to guide motorists towards the
centerline, while Fran Hanney suggested adding centerline rumble strips along
this section of roadway and under the bridge due to the number of sideswipe
Cobbs Creek Pkwy/Greenway Ave Intersection (A1/A2): PennDOT was
supportive of the crossing concept at this intersection and noted that pedestrian-
actuated rectangular rapid flashing beacons (RRFB's) would be the likely
pedestrian crossing treatment. The design should include full ADA compliance
including minimum distance to the push button for actuation. While this concept
was originally developed in support of A2, a crossing at Greenway Avenue would
also benefit A1 by improving access from the local neighborhood and calming
traffic along Cobbs Creek Parkway. Attendees agreed that this concept should be
included as a component of A1.
Woodland Ave/Island Ave Intersection: PennDOT was supportive of the
proposed intersection concept and did not offer any suggested modifications.
Island Avenue Alignment: PennDOT was supportive of a shared-use path
(SUP) adjacent to the roadway. They noted that detectable warning surfaces
(DWS) will be necessary across the full width of the path at driveway crossings
due to the activity generated by the commercial properties. Rebecca Christman
noted that the spacing between domes can range from 3/4" to 1.5" and attendees
agreed that the higher spacing would likely benefit cyclists.
Island Avenue/Amtrak Bridge: PennDOT was not supportive of using railing
under the bridge as shown in the section. It was agreed to replace the railing with
a 3-foot wide non-ridable textured area that would act as a separation between the
travel lanes and the SUP, which would then shift the SUP one foot closer to the
abutment. Since the vertical clearance is approximately 89" at a 2-foot distance
from the abutment, the SUP will meet the minimum 80" vertical clearance with
